title: reference request - arithmetic del Pezzo surfaces in comparison with del Pezzo surfaces over a field
body: A del Pezzo surface is a smooth, 2-dimensional projective variety $X$ with ample anticanonical divisor, i.e. a 2-dimensional Fano variety. I am interested in the arithmetic analogue, a 2-dimensional projective scheme $X$ with a relative 1-dimensional morphism to a Dedekind scheme $X \to S$ , such that the anticanonical divisor is ample. It would be sensible to require $X$ to be a regular scheme, but I would prefer not to require the structure morphism to $S$ to be smooth, as I would like to coexist peacefully with fibers of bad reduction. I am typically thinking of $S = \mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{Z}), \mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{Z}_p), \mathrm{Spec}(\mathbb{F}_q[t]), \mathbb{P}^1_{\mathbb{F}_q}$ , or finite extensions. Question : In what way are such objects analogous (or not) to del Pezzo surfaces over a field? By this I mean in terms of their intrinsic properties, and in how they may be distinguished from other surfaces in their respective area. Classical del Pezzo surfaces are quite special. Is there a specific name for such schemes? Some good references to read about them? I hoped to find something in Qing Liu's nice book, but have not found anything yet. reference-request arithmetic-geometry schemes algebraic-surfaces fano-varieties Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jul 19, 2020 at 20:30 asked Jul 19, 2020 at 19:43 PrimeRibeyeDeal 1,358 1 1 gold badge 12 12 silver badges 17 17 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 4 3 $\begingroup$ Since $X \to S$ is of relative dimension $1$, a smooth fibre must be a $\mathbf P^1$ if the relative anticanonical is ample. So this is more analogous to a ruled surface than a del Pezzo... $\endgroup$ R. van Dobben de Bruyn –  R. van Dobben de Bruyn 2020-07-19 19:48:54 +00:00 Commented Jul 19, 2020 at 19:48 1 $\begingroup$ @R.vanDobbendeBruyn Thanks. How does one prove this? I suspected the fibers would generally be simple, and perhaps you're right that a ruled surface is the better analogy. However I am particularly interested in the del Pezzo/Fano condition on the anticanonical bundle, as well as in the nonsmooth fibers, where the bulk of the action lies. $\endgroup$ PrimeRibeyeDeal –  PrimeRibeyeDeal 2020-07-19 20:28:17 +00:00 Commented Jul 19, 2020 at 20:28 1 $\begingroup$ Do you know Alessio Corti's paper "Del Pezzo surfaces over Dedekind schemes"? arxiv.org/pdf/alg-geom/9505036.pdf $\endgroup$ Francesco Polizzi –  Francesco Polizzi 2020-07-19 22:22:05 +00:00 Commented Jul 19, 2020 at 22:22 $\begingroup$ @FrancescoPolizzi No, I don't. Thank you, it does look interesting, but it appears to me to be one dimension too large for me. Is there a straightforward relationship? Of note is that the special fiber, an arithmetic surface, will never be mixed characteristic, which excludes the cases of most interest to me. $\endgroup$ PrimeRibeyeDeal –  PrimeRibeyeDeal 2020-07-19 22:31:58 +00:00 Commented Jul 19, 2020 at 22:31 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
